metadata.case_name: Plaintiff-Appellant v. Girija Nandan Bhagat & Narsingh Bhagat

facts.text: In the village of Turki in North Bihar there is a Math of the Kabirpanthi Bhagatatha Vairagi sect established over a century back. There are asthals subordinate to the principal one at Turki located in different districts of Bihar.
Devolution of the Mahantship has always been from a Guru to his Chela.
Defendant No. 2 executed a deed dated December 17, 1951 nominating the first defendant as his successor to the Mahantship.
Defendant No. 2 executed a second deed on September 15, 1952 surrendering his right to the Mahantship in favour of the first defendant with immediate effect.

The suit of the appellant was launched in 1959 for a declaration that he himself was the duly installed Mahant of saddar asthal Turki, that the second defendant had ceased to be the Mahant by his voluntary retirement and the first defendant being a junior Chela could have no right or claim to the Mahantship. As a corollary, he also asked for a decree for recovery of possession of all the properties of the asthal including those which had been purported to be transferred by the first two defendants.

Under the tenets and customs of the asthal and Bhagataha sect of Kabirpanthies, the devolution of the office of Mahantship is always from a Guru to the senior celibate Chela, either on the death of the Mahant or by the said Mahant nominating his successor by deed and himself retiring from the Mahantship. In either case, after the death or retirement, the senior chela succeeds and is duly installed on the Gaddi after performance of Bhandara in assemblage of Mahants and sadhus, at which the Chaddar of Mahanthi is bestowed by the Mahant of Acharya Math Dhanauti.
The deeds of 1951 and 1952 being in violation of the ancient custom of the asthal, the first defendant was never or became the Mahant of Turki nor was any Chaddar ceremony performed.
The appellant had filed a suit in the court of the Subordinate Judge at Muzaffarpur in the year 1953 for declaration of his rights and for setting aside the deeds of 1951 and 1952.

After the suit was pending for some time, a compromise was arrived at whereby it was agreed that the appellant should assume the office of Mahantship and take possession of all the properties of the Math. The appellant put his signature on a sheet of blank paper for recording the terms of settlement.
The appellant actually assumed the office of the Mahant of Turki in April 1954.

An elaborate ceremony was performed on the 16th February 1956 whereat the appellant was installed as the Mahant of Turki and given the Chaddar of Mahanti by the Acharya of Dhanauti before a big gathering. A document known as the Surat Hall was prepared regarding the plaintiff's installation. This bore the signature of innumerable persons.
This was followed by his taking charge of all the properties of the saddar and subordinate asthals.

The first two defendants thereafter dispossessed him and being unsuccessful in proceedings under the Code of Criminal Procedure for securing possession of the math and its properties, he was compelled to file the suit.

The custom and usages of the Turki Math relating to devolution of Mahantship was for the Mahant for the time being nominating a fit and proper person as his successor from amongst his Chelas irrespective of his seniority and the person so nominated invariably became the Mahant on the demise or retirement of the incumbent Mahant. A ceremony of installation of the new Mahant on the Gaddi and the bestowing of a Chaddar on him were not essential for establishing his title to this office.
The defendants denied the factum of the installation of the appellant relied on in the plaint.

The appellant had at all times knowledge of the nomination of the first defendant by the deed of December 17, 1951 and his appointment with immediate effect by the deed of September 15, 1952. It was on realisation of the weakness of his case that he had approached the defendants for a compromise agreeing to give up his claim in the suit of 1953. He had appended his signature to the petition of compromise in that suit being fully conversant with the terms thereof.

Two main issues framed by the trial court: custom governing the succession to the Mahantship of the Turki Math and the right of the incumbent mahant to nominate a junior Chela in preference to a senior Chela. Issues also as to whether an installation ceremony was an essential pre-requisite to a Mahant's lawfully functioning as such and whether the plaintiff had factually been installed as a Mahant of the Turki Math.

Trial court findings: From 1899 onwards only senior Chelas had succeeded their Gurus. According to the custom of the Muth the Mahant had the right to nominate his successor and the choice rested upon the senior Chela unless he suffered from any disqualification or was found to be unfit for the office. The right of nomination was not absolute but was subject to the approval of others. An installation ceremony was not essential to complete the title of the Mahant. Such a ceremony had been performed in the case of the plaintiff in 1956 and he became the Mahant of Turki although not in possession of the properties thereof at the time of the suit.

High Court rejected the custom as to succession set up by the plaintiff. Since the time of the founder, Chaturbhuj Gosala, six Mahants had occupied the office of whom three were described as junior Chelas by some of the witnesses on the defendants side. The evidence did not establish that there was an invariable custom of the senior Chela being nominated by the outgoing Mahant. The Mahant in office had an undoubted right to nominate his successor and ordinarily the right of appointment was exercised in favour of the senior Chela but the choice was exercised in favour of a celibate chela taking into account his all round ability and character. The second defendant had as a matter of fact nominated one Ganesh Bhagat as his successor even before the deed of nomination of 1951 in favour of the first defendant. This nomination of Ganesh Bhagat was cancelled as he was found to be unfit. Compared to the plaintiff, the first defendant was decidedly superior in learning, ability and conduct.

High Court did not examine the question as to whether an installation ceremony was necessary to perfect the title of Mahantship in view of the concession by counsel for the plaintiff. Differing from the finding of the trial court, the High Court held that no ceremony of installation of the plaintiff had been performed in 1956 as alleged in the plaint. The deeds of nomination and surrender in 1951 and 1952 by the first defendant were valid and binding.
Earliest document exhibited: 1899 executed by Mahant Lal Bahadur Bhagat in favour of Ram Bhagat describing him as the senior chela, able, clever, literate and by all means fit for the Mahantship.

Mahant Ram Bhagat nominated Mahadeo Bhagat as his successor by a deed of November 1910. Describes the nominee as able, clever and fit to discharge the duties of the Mahant. Mahadeo Bhagat not described as the senior Chela but only as a disciple.

By a deed of August 1937 Mahant Mahadeo Bhagat nominated Narsingh Bhagat, defendant No. 2 as his successor describing the latter as his only disciple worthy, clever and fit in all respects for the Gaddi.

By a document of June 1947 Narsingh Bhagat nominated one Ganesh Bhagat as his successor to the Gaddi. This nomination was cancelled by Narsingh Bhagat on the ground of unfitness of the nominee for the office but mention is made of the practice and custom relating to the succession.

The document of December 1951 by Narsingh Bhagat in favour of Girija Nandan Bhagat, the first defendant, describes the nominee as fit and qualified in all respects to be the Mahant and recites the custom as in the case of Ganesh Bhagat.
Ram Bhagat had a number of Chelas. Plaintiff in cross-examination stated Ram Gossai had 5 or 6 Chelas.

A fairly large number of witnesses stated that the qualifications for a person's nomination to the Mahantship did not depend only on seniority but on ability to manage, celibacy, adherence to religious principles and a habit of serving sadhus, fakirs and visitors besides a good moral character.

The plaintiff filed a petition under ss. 107 and 145 Cr. P.C. against the first defendant and 12 others on 8th December, 1956 describing himself as the Mahant of Chanwa Math and made no reference in the petition itself to the installation ceremony at Turki.
Admittedly Turki was a Mourasi Mutt.

legal_issues.text: What is the custom governing the succession to the Mahantship of the Turki Math - does it require nomination and succession to the senior celibate Chela, or can the Mahant nominate any fit Chela irrespective of seniority?
Does the right of the incumbent Mahant to nominate a junior Chela in preference to a senior Chela exist under the custom?
Is an installation ceremony an essential pre-requisite to a Mahant lawfully functioning as such?
Whether the plaintiff had factually been installed as a Mahant of the Turki Math.

petitioner_arguments.text: Under the tenets and customs of the asthal, devolution is to senior celibate Chela on death or nomination+retirement. Deeds of 1951/52 violate custom as first defendant junior Chela. No Chaddar ceremony for first defendant.
Compromise in 1953 suit allowed appellant to assume office. Installed in 1956 ceremony with Chaddar by Acharya Dhanauti, Surat Hall signed by many. Took possession thereafter.
From 1899 onwards only senior Chelas succeeded.

respondent_arguments.text: Custom allows Mahant to nominate fit Chela irrespective of seniority. Installation ceremony not essential.
Denied installation of appellant. Appellant knew of nominations, compromised 1953 suit fully aware.
Since founder, six Mahants, three junior Chelas. Nominated Ganesh before first defendant, cancelled for unfitness. First defendant superior in ability.

court_reasoning.text: General law on succession to Mahantship: In a Mutt, custom or practice of particular institution determines successor. If no grant, usage of institution to be followed, proved by evidence. Turki Mourasi Mutt: chela succeeds, eldest generally but junior if more capable and selected. Mahant may nominate by deed inter vivos.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Once a Mutt is established, succession takes place according to usages of particular institution.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence: Oral discrepant, mostly interested. Documentary reliable: 1899 senior, 1910 disciple not senior, 1937 only disciple, 1947 Ganesh (custom: appoints able Brahmachari disciple), 1951 Girija similar. Documents do not support invariable senior Chela.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Document of 1947 sets out custom accurately: Mahant appoints able Brahmachari disciple during lifetime.

court_reasoning.text: Oral evidence: Qualifications not only seniority but ability, celibacy, character, service. Seniority not decisive.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ability and efficiency in management coupled with good moral character entered into consideration.

court_reasoning.text: Installation argument abandoned before HC. Trial court found ceremony in 1956 but HC rejected: Surat Hall not produced earlier, Acharya denied signature, no handwriting expert; plaintiff in 1956 CrPC petition called himself Mahant of Chanwa Math, no mention of Turki installation; signed blank paper knowingly.

holdings.text: Plaintiff unable to discharge onus to substantiate custom of succession to senior Chela pleaded in plaint.
Plaintiff failed to establish he had in fact been installed as the Mahant.

precedents_cited.case_name: Decisions of the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council and some decisions of this Court
precedents_cited.relevance: General law as to succession to Mahantship well settled

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Proceedings by defendants unsuccessful; plaintiff's 1956 petition under these sections

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the Patna High Court's judgment reversing the trial court's decree in favour of the plaintiff-appellant, holding that the appellant failed to prove the custom of succession to the senior Chela or his own installation as Mahant. The deeds nominating the first defendant were valid.

key_quotes.text: "Once a Mutt is established, succession to headship takes place within the spiritual family according to the usages that grow up in a particular institution."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States the governing principle for succession in Mutts

key_quotes.text: "In a Mutt it is the custom or practice of a particular institution which determines as to how a successor is to be appointed."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "In our view the document executed by Narsingh Bhagat in favour of Ganesh Bhagat sets out the custom as to succession fairly accurately."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Relies on 1947 document to define custom allowing nomination of able disciple

key_quotes.text: "In the result we hold that the plaintiff was unable to discharge the onus which lay on him to substantiate the custom as to succession pleaded in his plaint."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Final holding on failure of proof
